bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, April 13, 1948

div1.p: Hench sends Lyons a photograph of Reed's grave for possible inclusion in the Hall of Fame exhibit, and discusses the courtesy lines to be used for individual items in the exhibit.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Bertha L. Lyons, April 13, 1948
div1.opener:
April 13, 1948
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
Assistant to the Director
Hall of Fame, New York University
1 Madison Avenue
New York City, 10, New York
My dear Miss Lyons:
div1.p:
I am sending you herewith two small photographs of Reed's grave taken
by me, and a large one taken by the U. S. Army Medical Museum. It is hard to
know which is the front and which is the back of the grave. As you will see, one
side has the cut inscription in the marble and this might be considered the front,
but the side which faces the road has his name at the bottom of the stone and a bronze
marker. I suppose that is really the front.

None of these pictures are very good. It is in a shady spot and the in-
scription would not be visible in a cut. I am sure that the Army Medical Museum
has a large one of the other side and since the film number of this one is 44042,
I suppose the film number of the other would be 44041 or 44043. I had a copy but
I simply can't find it. On Sunday, I actually spent four hours going through all
of my files and records, trying to find it for you but I think I must have loaned
it to the University of Virginia, although it is not listed specifically on the list
of data which I got from them.

Now this large one is my only copy. I am not waiting to have it copied
here, I am not sure it is good enough. You may use the two small ones any way you
wish but please return the large one to me. Thus, you can do one of three things:
(1) Use one of my small ones; (2) get a better print from the U. S. Army Medical
Museum, or (3) have a Washington photographer take a special one for you. Doubt-
less you have some connections in Washington. It wouldn't be much trouble for a
professional to go over to Arlington. The grave is easy to find. As I remember it,
one reports to the Lee House and it is just below the Lee House a short piece.

Now, for your letter of 9 April. I am using the numbers given by you in
that letter.
Item 2: Credit to U. S. Army Medical Museum (you left out the word Army).
Item 3: Can be credited to me.
Item 4: Should be credited to the Bettmann Archives. I am glad they loaned
it to you free.

As for Items 5 and 13, the letters from Walter Reed to Mrs. Walter Reed, I
think you should, by all means, say “By courtesy of Mrs. Walter Reed”. You do not
have to bother about any book because these letters, photostats of which I loaned
you, have never been published in photostatic form before. Extracts have been printed
but never published in photostatic form. I am sure that this is the first time, for
Miss Bertha L. Lyons
- 2 -
April 13, 1948
example, the well known New Year's letter has been published in photostatic form.

Now, these are the circumstances. Mrs. Walter Reed herself has always
been most courteous to me and in the first years when I knew her she did all she
could. However, she has failed so much that her obligations are carried on by her
son, General Walter Lawrence Reed and her daughter, Mrs. Blossom Reed. It was ac-
tually the son and daughter who together decided to put all of their collection of
data in my hands so as far as I am concerned, it was largely by the courtesy of
General Reed and Mrs. Blossom Reed that I have the material. As you know, I con-
sider myself merely the custodian of the material, not actually the personal owner.
There is only one possible reason why you might use the expression “By courtesy of
Mrs. Walter Reed and Dr. Philip S. Hench” and that is to prevent Mrs. Reed herself
from being bothered by people who, seeing your program, might want to borrow this or
that. I would certainly vote for having you say “By courtesy of Mrs. Walter Reed”.
It will be nice for the audience to know that she is still living.

I shall be delighted to receive from you when you are through with them the
better photographs of the birthplace and the Walter Reed General Hospital. I don't
actually know when the hospital was established, that is, the official date. I have
two or three dates, one when they first talked about it and the government ordered
it built and one when they broke ground, etc., but what date the Army considers the
official date I do not know and I suggest you write to the commanding general of
Walter Reed Hospital.

As for Item 8, you say it is a letter from General Reed to Major Kean, Septem-
ber 6, 1900. I am not sure whether I have ever seen this letter. Perhaps General
Kean gave me a copy. Do you mean that it is from Major Walter Reed or from Lieutenant
(now General) Reed?
Item 9: Again this should be handled like Items 5 and 13.
Item 11: Same as for Items 5, 9 and 13. This letter is in my possession,
I merely loaned it to the University of Virginia. It has never been published photo-
statically.
Item 14: Please don't credit this to me. Please credit it to Dr. L. O.
Howard. Dr. Howard is now quite senile and his daughter, Miss Lucy Howard gave me
the photostat. She has the actual letter. Please write her at 45 Pondfield Road
West, Bronxville, New York.

I am sorry that you see fit to leave out the medal. A Congressional Medal
of course, carries a high rating and even though actually Major Reed never saw this
medal as it was granted by Congress many years after his death; nevertheless, the
fact that Congress so honored him and his colleagues is most impressive. Did you know
that the names of Reed and his colleagues are the only names published (by law) every
year on the Roll of Honor of the Army. All other names are published usually just once.

I am sending a note to General Reed and Mrs. Blossom Reed asking them about
the matter of referring directly to their mother. In my opinion this is certainly
what should be done unless they wish otherwise, in which case you might say “By courtesy
of the family of Major Reed”, or some such.

You ask me to let you know what the prints cost. I don't want these to
cost you anything. As I told you, the Clinic printed some and I had others printed
in town, but I should like to make this small contribution to your venture and you
can more than repay me by doing two things: (1) Let me have a fairly good seat at
the affair and (2) Let me have the privilege of paying for about 50 programs. I
correspond with a great many people in regard to this hobby of mine and I know many
of them would love to have a program. At this early date, you could probably con-
tract to have 50 extra programs printed at my expense. I don't imagine it would be
very much.
Mrs. Hench will not be along.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
